poem:
Title: Macbeth's Mimicry

Beehive of ambition, sphere for a sceptre,
Macbeth's hand grasps the air where a dagger's phantom cowers, 
Juggler's ring fashioned to the helm,
Acrobat king, regality overwhelms. 
Spotless stage, but crime veils the ether,
Invisible ink bleeding slyly, a silent spectre. 
Stock props absent, yet tragedy's tale grows stronger,
Bare of blood, yet guilt echoes longer.
prompt: You are the poet Simon Armitage. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "‘It’s a beehive’: Tero Saarinen’s mighty Macbeth puts Helsinki’s first dance house on the map Is this a dagger I see before me? Not at all. Macbeth is centre-stage and thrusting a hand towards a juggler’s ring instead of a weapon. A handful of rings are then fashioned into a crown that is precariously balanced atop the acrobat’s head. There are no other props, and not a damned spot of stage blood, in this uncommon". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
